p: In order to inhibit the MeV growth, a strategy is to silence mRNAs encoding one of the key polymerase complex, namely N, P or L using small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) or shRNAs, as synthetic oligonucleotides, encoded by plasmids, or transduced using lentiviral vectors. siRNAs targeting the mRNA of either L [ 238] or N [ 239] or P [ 240], or the three in combination [ 241] have shown their efficiency in preventing virus growth over few days without cytotoxic effect. However, MeV finally escapes the silencing even in cells that constitutively express the siRNAs without acquiring any mutation even those that could disrupt the siRNA target sequence [ 240]. This likely reflects the remarkable long half-life of the polymerase brought by the incoming virus particles that last at least over 24 h [ 242, 243] and the saturation of the siRNA linked to the continuous viral mRNA synthesis by the incoming polymerases.
